Description: Body sherd (mended from two fragments) of Milesian Fikellura pottery neck-amphora; beige slip; exterior: painted decoration consisting of padded dancers in a komos scene (from left, hand of one dancer; at centre, chest, arm, rump and thigh of second dancer with figure on his shoulders, of which only legs and part of head remain; at right, outstretched hand of fourth figure); blobs and dots as filling ornament.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The sherd belongs to the same vase as Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR.302.1899 and GR.52.1899. Schaus lists the sherd as probably belonging to the Altenburg Painter. According to Cook's classification system, the sherd belongs in the Cambridge Group (named after this sherd Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR.52.1899 and GR.302.1899); the human figures are rudimentary but resemble those from the Altenburg Group. See Cook 1933-1934 pls. 5, 6, 11c, for the group's namepiece, the amphora, Altenburg 191.
Bibliographic references: CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 36, no. 7, pl. XVIII, no. 7)
Edgar 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis. B: The Inscribed and Painted Pottery (p. 60, pl. VI, no. 12b)

Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 246, no. 4)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GF.020)
